channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: The enigmas of language and immunology, and other reads: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00624-5

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: The enigmas of language and immunology, and other reads: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: ‘This is my calling’: building point-of-care diagnostic tools to fight tuberculosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00625-4

Mireille Kamariza talks about her journey from community college to biotech chief executive, and the uphill battle to stop the spread of the deadly lung disease.
item.dc:title: ‘This is my calling’: building point-of-care diagnostic tools to fight tuberculosis
item.dc:creator: Abdullahi Tsanni

item.title: Galapagos giant tortoises were supersized before arrival
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00567-x

Fossil analysis suggests the reptiles were already huge when they rode ocean currents to the islands thousands or even millions of years ago.
item.dc:title: Galapagos giant tortoises were supersized before arrival

item.title: Submerged volcano’s eruption was the biggest since the last ice age
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00565-z

Some 7,300 years ago, the Kikai volcano in Japan produced up to 457 cubic kilometres of ash and other debris.
item.dc:title: Submerged volcano’s eruption was the biggest since the last ice age

item.title: Mpox’s surge was stopped by behaviour change — before vaccine rollout
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00566-y

Analysis of more than 1,000 viral genomes reveals patterns in how the disease circulated through various communities.
item.dc:title: Mpox’s surge was stopped by behaviour change — before vaccine rollout

item.title: This dying star bears a jagged metal scar
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00564-0

The surface of a white dwarf is marked with metallic patches — souvenirs of its encounter with an asteroid or planet.
item.dc:title: This dying star bears a jagged metal scar

item.title: Two giant US telescopes threatened by funding cap
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00623-6

Thirty Meter Telescope and Giant Magellan Telescope might need to compete for survival in face of federal spending limit.
item.dc:title: Two giant US telescopes threatened by funding cap
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Robot, repair thyself: laying the foundations for self-healing machines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00597-5

Advances in materials science and sensing could deliver robots that can mend themselves and feel pain.
item.dc:title: Robot, repair thyself: laying the foundations for self-healing machines
item.dc:creator: Simon Makin

item.title: Editorial Expression of Concern: p63 and p73 are required for p53-dependent apoptosis in response to DNA damage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07223-4

Editorial Expression of Concern: p63 and p73 are required for p53-dependent apoptosis in response to DNA damage
item.dc:title: Editorial Expression of Concern: p63 and p73 are required for p53-dependent apoptosis in response to DNA damage
item.dc:creator: Elsa R. Flores
Kenneth Y. Tsai
Denise Crowley
Shomit Sengupta
Annie Yang
Frank McKeon
Tyler Jacks

item.title: Symmetry breaking and chiral amplification in prebiotic ligation reactions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07059-y

A study of a new route to proteinogenic peptides reveals how heterochiral preference can lead to homochiral peptides in a prebiotic world.
item.dc:title: Symmetry breaking and chiral amplification in prebiotic ligation reactions
item.dc:creator: Min Deng
Jinhan Yu
Donna G. Blackmond

item.title: Anti-TIGIT antibody improves PD-L1 blockade through myeloid and T<sub>reg</sub> cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07121-9

A high baseline of intratumoural macrophages and regulatory T cells is associated with better outcomes in patients with non-small cell lung cancer treated with atezolizumab plus tiragolumab, but not with atezolizumab alone.
item.dc:title: Anti-TIGIT antibody improves PD-L1 blockade through myeloid and T<sub>reg</sub> cells
item.dc:creator: Xiangnan Guan

item.title: The CRL5–SPSB3 ubiquitin ligase targets nuclear cGAS for degradation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07112-w

The ubiquitin proteasomal system degrades nuclear cGAS in cycling cells.
item.dc:title: The CRL5–SPSB3 ubiquitin ligase targets nuclear cGAS for degradation
item.dc:creator: Pengbiao Xu
Ying Liu
Chong Liu
Baptiste Guey
Lingyun Li
Pauline Melenec
Jonathan Ricci
Andrea Ablasser

item.title: Incomplete transcripts dominate the Mycobacterium tuberculosis transcriptome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07105-9

A study reveals that most transcripts in Mycobacterium tuberculosis are incomplete, likely because of the tendency of the transcription machinery in this species to pause on genomic DNA.
item.dc:title: Incomplete transcripts dominate the Mycobacterium tuberculosis transcriptome
item.dc:creator: Xiangwu Ju
Shuqi Li
Ruby Froom
Ling Wang
Mirjana Lilic
Madeleine Delbeau
Elizabeth A. Campbell
Jeremy M. Rock
Shixin Liu

item.title: Neuronal dynamics direct cerebrospinal fluid perfusion and brain clearance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07108-6

Rhythmic neural activity drives cerebrospinal fluid perfusion through brain parenchyma to enhance brain cleansing.
item.dc:title: Neuronal dynamics direct cerebrospinal fluid perfusion and brain clearance
item.dc:creator: Li-Feng Jiang-Xie
Antoine Drieu
Kesshni Bhasiin
Daniel Quintero
Igor Smirnov
Jonathan Kipnis

item.title: Mutualisms weaken the latitudinal diversity gradient among oceanic islands
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07110-y

The effect of the latitudinal diversity gradient on plants on oceanic islands is weakened by classical abiotic physical drivers of island biogeography and, to a greater extent, by mutualism with other species.
item.dc:title: Mutualisms weaken the latitudinal diversity gradient among oceanic islands
item.dc:creator: Camille S. Delavaux
Thomas W. Crowther
James D. Bever
Patrick Weigelt
Evan M. Gora

item.title: Durable and efficient gene silencing in vivo by hit-and-run epigenome editing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07087-8

Experiments in mice show that designed epigenome editors that contain domains of transcriptional repressors can enable stable epigenetic silencing of Pcsk9, a gene with a role in cholesterol homeostasis, without inducing DNA breaks.
item.dc:title: Durable and efficient gene silencing in vivo by hit-and-run epigenome editing
item.dc:creator: Martino Alfredo Cappelluti
Valeria Mollica Poeta
Sara Valsoni
Piergiuseppe Quarato
Simone Merlin
Ivan Merelli
Angelo Lombardo

item.title: Latitudinal patterns in stabilizing density dependence of forest communities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07118-4

An analysis of tree survival data from forest sites worldwide shows that in the tropics, rare tree species experience stronger stabilizing density dependence than common species, wheras no correlation of stabilizing density dependence and abundance exists in the temperate zone.
item.dc:title: Latitudinal patterns in stabilizing density dependence of forest communities

item.title: CST–polymerase α-primase solves a second telomere end-replication problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07137-1

Incomplete duplication of the C-rich telomeric repeat strand by lagging-strand DNA synthesis is counteracted by DNA synthesis mediated by CST–polymerase α-primase.
item.dc:title: CST–polymerase α-primase solves a second telomere end-replication problem
item.dc:creator: Hiroyuki Takai
Valentina Aria
Pamela Borges
Joseph T. P. Yeeles
Titia de Lange

item.title: Identifying general reaction conditions by bandit optimization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07021-y

Bandit optimization models are used to identify generally applicable conditions by efficient condition sampling and evaluation of experimental feedback.
item.dc:title: Identifying general reaction conditions by bandit optimization
item.dc:creator: Jason Y. Wang
Jason M. Stevens

item.title: Imaging the Meissner effect in hydride superconductors using quantum sensors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07026-7

In order to explore superconductivity in hydride materials, local magnetometry inside a diamond anvil cell is performed with sub-micron spatial resolution at megabar pressures using nitrogen-vacancy colour centres.
item.dc:title: Imaging the Meissner effect in hydride superconductors using quantum sensors
item.dc:creator: P. Bhattacharyya

item.title: Ligand-channel-enabled ultrafast Li-ion conduction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07045-4

An electrolyte design using small-sized fluoroacetonitrile solvents to form a ligand channel produces lithium-ion batteries simultaneously achieving high energy density, fast charging and wide operating temperature range, desirable features for batteries working in extreme conditions.
item.dc:title: Ligand-channel-enabled ultrafast Li-ion conduction
item.dc:creator: Di Lu
Ruhong Li

item.title: Integrated lithium niobate microwave photonic processing engine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07078-9

An integrated lithium niobate photonic processing engine performs integration and differentiation of analogue signals, solves ordinary differential equations, generates ultra-wideband microwave signals and detects edges in images.
item.dc:title: Integrated lithium niobate microwave photonic processing engine
item.dc:creator: Hanke Feng
Tong Ge

item.title: An atlas of epithelial cell states and plasticity in lung adenocarcinoma
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07113-9

Analyses of single epithelial cells from early-stage lung adenocarcinoma and normal lung identifies a population of intermediate cells that may have an increased likelihood of transforming to tumour cells after injury such as tobacco exposure.
item.dc:title: An atlas of epithelial cell states and plasticity in lung adenocarcinoma
item.dc:creator: Guangchun Han

item.title: Multisensory gamma stimulation promotes glymphatic clearance of amyloid
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07132-6

Audio and visual stimulation at 40 Hz promote cerebrospinal and interstitial fluid flux in mouse brain and result in amyloid clearance via the glymphatic system in a mouse model of Alzheimer’s disease.
item.dc:title: Multisensory gamma stimulation promotes glymphatic clearance of amyloid
item.dc:creator: Mitchell H. Murdock

item.title: High fatigue resistance in a titanium alloy via near-void-free 3D printing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07048-1

We successfully rebuild an approximate void-free additive manufacturing microstructure in Ti-6Al-4V titanium alloy by the development of a void-free additive manufacturing processing technique through an understanding of the asynchronism of phase transformation and grain growth.
item.dc:title: High fatigue resistance in a titanium alloy via near-void-free 3D printing

item.title: SOX17 enables immune evasion of early colorectal adenomas and cancers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07135-3

Transcriptomic and chromatin accessibility analyses of naive and transplanted colon cancer organoids in a mouse model reveal a key role for the transcription factor SOX17 in establishing a permissive immune environment for tumour cells.
item.dc:title: SOX17 enables immune evasion of early colorectal adenomas and cancers
item.dc:creator: Norihiro Goto

item.title: Most of the photons that reionized the Universe came from dwarf galaxies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07043-6

An analysis of eight ultra-faint galaxies during the epoch of reionization with absolute magnitudes between −17 mag and −15  mag shows that most of the photons that reionized the Universe come from dwarf galaxies.
item.dc:title: Most of the photons that reionized the Universe came from dwarf galaxies

item.title: Ion and lipid orchestration of secondary active transport
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07062-3

This Review describes the various mechanisms of ion-coupled transport across membranes and how the activities of transporter proteins are modulated by the composition of the lipid bilayer.
item.dc:title: Ion and lipid orchestration of secondary active transport
item.dc:creator: David Drew
Olga Boudker

item.title: Site-specific reactivity of stepped Pt surfaces driven by stress release
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07090-z

Stress release at stepped platinum surfaces is shown to influence the strain experienced by atoms near the steps, resulting in effects on the catalytic activity of the whole surface.
item.dc:title: Site-specific reactivity of stepped Pt surfaces driven by stress release
item.dc:creator: Guangdong Liu
Arthur J. Shih
Huiqiu Deng
Kasinath Ojha
Xiaoting Chen
Mingchuan Luo

Marc T. M. Koper

Zhenhua Zeng

item.title: On the genetic basis of tail-loss evolution in humans and apes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07095-8

An insertion of an Alu element into an intron of the TBXT gene is identified as a genetic mechanism of tail-loss evolution in humans and apes, with implications for human health today.
item.dc:title: On the genetic basis of tail-loss evolution in humans and apes
item.dc:creator: Bo Xia
Weimin Zhang

item.title: Compartmentalized ocular lymphatic system mediates eye–brain immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07130-8

A study provides evidence for a shared lymphatic circuit that connects the posterior eye and the brain, allowing the generation of immune responses to protect the CNS against pathogens and tumours following intravitreal immunization.
item.dc:title: Compartmentalized ocular lymphatic system mediates eye–brain immunity
item.dc:creator: Xiangyun Yin

item.title: Crym-positive striatal astrocytes gate perseverative behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07138-0

In mice, a population of astrocytes in the central striatum, characterized by expression of μ-crystallin, has a role in perseveration phenotypes that are often associated with human neuropsychiatric disorders.
item.dc:title: Crym-positive striatal astrocytes gate perseverative behaviour
item.dc:creator: Matthias Ollivier

item.title: The Dimorphos ejecta plume properties revealed by LICIACube
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06998-2

Dimorphos ejecta plume properties were revealed by the observations from the LICIACube cube satellite, which was deployed 15  days in advance of the impact of DART.
item.dc:title: The Dimorphos ejecta plume properties revealed by LICIACube

item.title: Mechanisms of calcium homeostasis orchestrate plant growth and immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07100-0

A study of calcium homeostasis in the plant Arabidopsis reveals two signalling pathways it uses to balance the objectives of growth and immunity by regulating the level of Ca2+ in the cytosol.
item.dc:title: Mechanisms of calcium homeostasis orchestrate plant growth and immunity
item.dc:creator: Chao Wang
Ren-Jie Tang
Senhao Kou
Xiaoshu Xu
Yi Lu
Kenda Rauscher
Angela Voelker
Sheng Luan

item.title: Supramolecular polymers form tactoids through liquid–liquid phase separation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07034-7

Spontaneous liquid–liquid phase-separation behaviour of high-aspect-ratio fibrils, obtained from supramolecular polymerizations of synthetic components, forms tactoids by means of an entropy-driven pathway.
item.dc:title: Supramolecular polymers form tactoids through liquid–liquid phase separation
item.dc:creator: Hailin Fu
Jingyi Huang

E. W. Meijer

item.title: Could this one-time ‘epigenetic’ treatment control cholesterol?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00609-4

Regulating gene expression lowers blood cholesterol in mice, and how the Universe’s cosmic fog was lifted.
item.dc:title: Could this one-time ‘epigenetic’ treatment control cholesterol?
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Non-neuronal brain cells modulate behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00425-w

A single gene in astrocytes can constrain repetitive behaviours, indicating that these cells are regulators of behavioural disruption in conditions such as Huntington’s disease and obsessive–compulsive disorder.
item.dc:title: Non-neuronal brain cells modulate behaviour
item.dc:creator: Anna Kruyer

item.title: Adding scientific signs to Indian Sign Language will create a more inclusive field for deaf students
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00611-w

Digvijay Singh, a deaf sign-language educator, works with biology researchers and sign-language specialists to add to the scientific lexicon for deaf students in India.
item.dc:title: Adding scientific signs to Indian Sign Language will create a more inclusive field for deaf students
item.dc:creator: Deepa Padmanaban

item.title: Eyes on history
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00338-8

Passing time.
item.dc:title: Eyes on history
item.dc:creator: Yelena Crane

item.title: Can non-profits beat antibiotic resistance and soaring drug costs?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00543-5

Effective, affordable antimicrobial drugs aren’t moneymakers, despite being desperately needed. Can non-profit organizations pick up the slack?
item.dc:title: Can non-profits beat antibiotic resistance and soaring drug costs?
item.dc:creator: Maryn McKenna

item.title: Stealthy stem cells to treat disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00590-y

Gene-editing strategies that allow stem cells to evade the immune system offer hope for universal cell-replacement therapies.
item.dc:title: Stealthy stem cells to treat disease
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Quantum sensor settles debate about superconductivity in hydrides
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00423-y

By adapting a device designed to create extremely high pressures into one that can sense magnetic fields, researchers have obtained evidence that a hydrogen-rich material is a superconductor, eliminating long-standing doubts.
item.dc:title: Quantum sensor settles debate about superconductivity in hydrides
item.dc:creator: Kin On Ho
Sen Yang

item.title: Self-assembling synthetic polymer forms liquid-like droplets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00421-0

The molecules of liquid crystals and proteins can form liquid-like condensates, but such a phenomenon had not been observed for supramolecular polymers, which are held together by non-covalent bonds — until now.
item.dc:title: Self-assembling synthetic polymer forms liquid-like droplets
item.dc:creator: Jennifer L. Ross

item.title: Mechanisms guiding the slow pace of maturation in human neurons uncovered
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04141-9

Nerve cells in the human brain take a remarkably long time to mature. This study identifies an epigenetic ‘barrier’ in neural precursor cells that determines the rate of neuronal maturation and is slowly released during the process. Inhibition of the barrier is shown to accelerate maturation in multiple human stem-cell-based models.
item.dc:title: Mechanisms guiding the slow pace of maturation in human neurons uncovered

item.title: ‘Epigenetic’ editing cuts cholesterol in mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00563-1

Changes to chemical tags on DNA in mice dial down the activity of a gene without cuts to the genome.
item.dc:title: ‘Epigenetic’ editing cuts cholesterol in mice
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: How humans lost their tails — and why the discovery took 2.5 years to publish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00610-x

An elegant run of experiments in mice reveals the genetic changes that led humanity’s ape ancestors to lose the appendage.
item.dc:title: How humans lost their tails — and why the discovery took 2.5 years to publish
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: A mobile DNA sequence could explain tail loss in humans and apes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00309-z

The lack of a tail is one thing that separates apes — including humans — from other primates. Insertion of a short DNA sequence into a gene that controls tail development could explain tail loss in the common ancestor of apes.
item.dc:title: A mobile DNA sequence could explain tail loss in humans and apes
item.dc:creator: Miriam K. Konkel
Emily L. Casanova

item.title: How dwarf galaxies lit up the Universe after the Big Bang
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00594-8

Some of the faintest objects ever observed suggest that small galaxies get the credit for clearing the ‘fog’ pervading the early cosmos.
item.dc:title: How dwarf galaxies lit up the Universe after the Big Bang
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: Tiny sheaths of solvent boost battery performance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00378-0

Small solvent molecules have been found to enable a previously unknown ion-transport mechanism in battery electrolytes, speeding up charging and increasing performance at low temperatures.
item.dc:title: Tiny sheaths of solvent boost battery performance
item.dc:creator: Chong Yan
Jia-Qi Huang

item.title: Synchronized neuronal activity drives waste fluid flow
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00422-z

Active neurons can stimulate the clearance of their own metabolic waste by driving changes to ion gradients in the surrounding fluid and by promoting the pulsation of nearby blood vessels.
item.dc:title: Synchronized neuronal activity drives waste fluid flow
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hablitz
Maiken Nedergaard

item.title: Is ChatGPT making scientists hyper-productive? The highs and lows of using AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00592-w

Large language models are transforming scientific writing and publishing. But the productivity boost that these tools bring could come with a downside.
item.dc:title: Is ChatGPT making scientists hyper-productive? The highs and lows of using AI
item.dc:creator: McKenzie Prillaman

item.title: Private Moon lander is dying — it scored some wins for science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00613-8

The Odysseus spacecraft gathered data successfully from the lunar surface.
item.dc:title: Private Moon lander is dying — it scored some wins for science
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Russia’s Arctic Council threat requires lessons from cold war science diplomacy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00557-z

Russia’s Arctic Council threat requires lessons from cold war science diplomacy
item.dc:title: Russia’s Arctic Council threat requires lessons from cold war science diplomacy
item.dc:creator: Paul Arthur Berkman

item.title: Europe needs a joined-up approach for monitoring and protecting its forests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00558-y

Europe needs a joined-up approach for monitoring and protecting its forests
item.dc:title: Europe needs a joined-up approach for monitoring and protecting its forests
item.dc:creator: Marco Ferretti

item.title: Speed up relief for long COVID through grassroots clinical trials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00560-4

Speed up relief for long COVID through grassroots clinical trials
item.dc:title: Speed up relief for long COVID through grassroots clinical trials
item.dc:creator: Marc Jamoulle
Elena Louazon

item.title: Japanese Moon-lander unexpectedly survives the lunar night
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00593-9

Its engineers never gave up hope, but the Moon-lander continues to beat the odds.
item.dc:title: Japanese Moon-lander unexpectedly survives the lunar night
item.dc:creator: Ling Xin

item.title: From the archive: Stephen Hawking’s explosive idea, and scientific spirit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00429-6

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: Stephen Hawking’s explosive idea, and scientific spirit

item.title: Train young scientists in taxonomy to help solve the biodiversity crisis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00559-x

Train young scientists in taxonomy to help solve the biodiversity crisis
item.dc:title: Train young scientists in taxonomy to help solve the biodiversity crisis
item.dc:creator: Dasheng Liu
Julian R. Thompson
Jun Gao
Henglun Shen

item.title: ‘Education is possible in any situation’ — what I’ve learnt from teaching in Kyiv amid a war
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00588-6

Ukraine’s universities have adapted by blending innovative forms of remote learning. Lessons from this experiment are relevant to the rest of the world.
item.dc:title: ‘Education is possible in any situation’ — what I’ve learnt from teaching in Kyiv amid a war
item.dc:creator: Inna Makhovych

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: AI reveals US climate denial hotspots
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00607-6

Just under 15% of people in the United States deny that climate change is happening, according to an analysis of more than seven million social media posts. Plus, Neuralink’s ‘brain reading’ implant underwhelms and what happens when chatbots go off the rails.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: AI reveals US climate denial hotspots
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Daily briefing: Influential abortion pill studies retracted
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00617-4

Publisher has retracted two papers that suggested the abortion drug mifepristone causes a burden on US public health. Plus, learn how the ‘flashlight’ method can boost research team meetings and see a sensational sea toad.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Influential abortion pill studies retracted
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Influential abortion-pill studies retracted: the science behind the decision
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00556-0

Nature spoke to researchers about the flaws that triggered the retractions. They say these papers are just the tip of the iceberg.
item.dc:title: Influential abortion-pill studies retracted: the science behind the decision
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Daily briefing: Are gut bacteria causing eye diseases?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00605-8

Experiments in mice suggest that some eye diseases might be caused in part by escapee bacteria. Plus, giant ‘bubble’ in space could be source of powerful cosmic rays and why live music makes us more emotional than recordings.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Are gut bacteria causing eye diseases?
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Fresh tools for watching the ‘lava lamps’ of living cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00547-1

Imaging and molecular manipulation reveal how biomolecular condensates form and offer clues to the role of phase separation in health and disease.
item.dc:title: Fresh tools for watching the ‘lava lamps’ of living cells
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: How I made my lab meetings more inclusive with a rapid-relay technique
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00580-0

Johanna Joyce’s use of the ‘flashlight’ method has helped her lab members to connect and be more mindful about their science.
item.dc:title: How I made my lab meetings more inclusive with a rapid-relay technique
item.dc:creator: Johanna Joyce

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00574-y

Scientists have identified a region in the Milky Way capable of accelerating particles to super-high energy levels.
item.dc:title: Giant ‘bubble’ in space could be source of powerful cosmic rays

item.title: ‘Incomprehensible’: scientists in France decry €900-million cut to research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00589-5

A €10-billion reduction in public spending in response to a revised economic forecast includes cuts to higher-education and research budgets.
item.dc:title: ‘Incomprehensible’: scientists in France decry €900-million cut to research

item.title: The surprising link between gut bacteria and devastating eye diseases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00562-2

Finding raises hopes that antibiotics could treat some genetic diseases that can cause blindness — but also prompts doubts.
item.dc:title: The surprising link between gut bacteria and devastating eye diseases

item.title: Earthquakes are most deadly in these unexpected countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00508-8

Haiti and Turkmenistan are among the nations with the highest earthquake fatality load, a measure of the burden imposed by quake-related deaths.
item.dc:title: Earthquakes are most deadly in these unexpected countries
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: Why the US border remains ‘a place of terror’ for Chinese researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00546-2

Two years after the end of the controversial China Initiative, academics describe being treated like spies, a loss of talent and a chilling atmosphere that is stifling science.
item.dc:title: Why the US border remains ‘a place of terror’ for Chinese researchers
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: I help researchers build fantastic funding proposals — here’s how
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00579-7

Glòria García-Negredo supports scientists who are writing grant applications, and creates links between research groups.
